title: Contributing to gigs
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , can use usethis::create_from_github("lshtm-gigs/gigs", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described tidyverse style guide.

title: Contributing to gigs
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle existing code altered part PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Benchmarking gigs against other software packages
text: short article describes performance gigs relative non-exhaustive group R non-R packages designed implement child growth standards. Thus far, comprehensive benchmark comparing different packages. short article compare speed package 1 100000 inputs, checking fast package can convert weight values z-scores Child Growth standards. performed benchmarks Windows 10 system running Ryzen 7 3700X processor 16GB DDR4 RAM, using R version 4.3.2. Stata benchmarks run system Stata 18.0 (revision 15 May 2023), using benchmark package Stata.

title: Benchmarking gigs against other software packages
text: benchmarking package comparisons use 100,000-row dataset comprised data can used convert z-scores centiles weight--age standard. z-scores, x variable sexes row generated randomly pre-specified seed. gigs validated published growth curve data , use generate weight values kg observation. dataset can used compare speed accuracy conversion values z-scores/centiles packages mentioned . first 10 rows dataset look like :
code: who_gs_dataset <- function(n, acronym = "wfa", seed = 154237890) {   withr::with_seed(     seed,     code = {       # Random z-scores around 0       z <- rnorm(n = n)       # X variables are non-discrete but within bounds of the desired acronym       xvars <- gigs::who_gs_coeffs[[acronym]][[1]][, 1]       x <-  sample(xvars, size = n, replace = TRUE)       x_jitter <- c(runif(n = 5, min = -1, max = 1), 0)       x <- x + sample(x_jitter, size = n, replace = TRUE)       x <- pmax(pmin(x, max(xvars)), min(xvars))       # Sexes randomly sampled from male and female       sex <- sample(c("M", "F"), size = n, replace = TRUE)     }   )   acronym <- rep_len(acronym, n)   out <- data.frame(z = z, x = x, sex = sex, acronym = acronym) |>     dplyr::mutate(       y = gigs::who_gs_zscore2value(z = z, x = x, sex = sex, acronym = acronym)     )   purrr::set_names(out, c("z", "x", "sex", "acronym", "y")) }  # Generate 100,000-row dataset bench_dataset <- who_gs_dataset(n = 100000) bench_dataset[1:10, ]

title: Benchmarking gigs against other software packages
text: mbench_pkg() function used benchmark package range input sizes. call produces tabular output containing median time required pkg_expr operate data, ranging 1 100,000 inputs.
code: mbench_pkg <- function(pkg_expr, pkg_name) {   n_inputs <- c(1, 10, 100, 500, 1000, 5000, 10000, 25000, 50000, 75000, 100000)   purrr::map_dfr(.x = n_inputs,                  .f = \(no_of_inputs) {                    dataset <- bench_dataset[seq_len(no_of_inputs), ]                    mbench <- microbenchmark::microbenchmark(                      dplyr::mutate(dataset, test = eval(pkg_expr)),                      times = 25                    )                    c(n_inputs = no_of_inputs,                      median_time = summary(mbench)$median,                      time_units = attr(summary(mbench), which = "unit"))                  }) |>     dplyr::mutate(n_inputs = as.integer(n_inputs),                   median_time = as.numeric(median_time),                   package = pkg_name) }

title: Benchmarking gigs against other software packages
code: anthro_timings <- mbench_pkg(   pkg_expr = quote(anthro::anthro_zscores(sex = sex,                                           age = x,                                           weight = y)$zwei),   pkg_name = paste("R: anthro", packageVersion(pkg = "anthro")) )

title: Benchmarking gigs against other software packages
code: childsds_timings <- mbench_pkg(   pkg_expr = quote(childsds::sds(value = y,                                  age = x / 365.25,                                  sex = sex,                                  male = "M",                                  female = "F",                                  item = "weight",                                  ref = childsds::who.ref)),   pkg_name = paste("R: childsds", packageVersion(pkg = "childsds")) )

title: Benchmarking gigs against other software packages
code: growthstandards_timings <- mbench_pkg(   pkg_expr = quote(     growthstandards::who_value2zscore(y = y, x = x,                                       sex = ifelse(sex == "M", "Male",                                                    "Female"),                                       y_var = "wtkg")   ),   pkg_name = paste("R: growthstandards",                    packageVersion(pkg = "growthstandards")) )

code: gigs_timings <- mbench_pkg(   pkg_expr = quote(gigs::who_gs_value2zscore(y = y, x = x, sex = sex,                                              acronym = acronym)),   pkg_name = paste("R: gigs", packageVersion(pkg = "gigs")) )

title: Benchmarking gigs against other software packages
text: Stata, commands run inside -file utilises benchmark package Stata. script essentially mbench_pkg(), Stata gigs package zanthro package. outputs script give table timings look like :
code: # Save .dta file equivalent of benchmarking table. This can be used to benchmark # Stata packages. haven::write_dta(data = bench_dataset,                  path = file.path("exclude", "statabench", "bench_dataset.dta")) // This is Stata code foreach i in 1 10 100 500 1000 5000 10000 25000 50000 75000 100000 {     use "benchmarking/bench_dataset.dta", clear     qui drop if _n > `i'     di "Number of inputs: `i'"     bench, reps(25) restore last: ///         qui egen double z_gigs = who_gs(y, "wfa", "v2z"), ///         xvar(x) sex(sex) sexcode(m=M, f=F) }  foreach i in 1 10 100 500 1000 5000 10000 25000 50000 75000 100000 {     use "benchmarking/bench_dataset.dta", clear     qui drop if _n > `i'     di "Number of inputs: `i'"     bench, reps(25) restore last: ///         qui egen z_anthro = zanthro(y, wa, WHO), xvar(x) gender(sex) ///                 gencode(male=M, female=F) ageunit(day) } stata_timings ## title: Benchmarking gigs against other software packages
text: plotting various timings tables can see trends package:  whole, anthro far slowest R package, taking around 2.24 seconds process 100,000 inputs. part anthro computes results every Child Growth standard time anthro::anthro_zscores() called, also due slower implementation LMS process conversion packages. Next slowest Stata package zanthro, takes around 2.05 seconds compute results single standard. 4 times faster zanthro gigs Stata 0.4.0, scales efficiently zanthro takes around 0.41 seconds convert 100,000 measurements z-scores. Leading pack three R implementations: growthstandards, gigs, childsds. growthstandards package fastest ~125 ms 100,000 inputs, followed gigs (~128 ms) childsds (~126 ms).

title: Benchmarking gigs against other software packages
text: packages also differ slightly convert values centiles/z-scores, can affect z-scores computed package even inputs . testing standards, found tested packages mostly agreed , childsds correctly perform z-scoring standards. Child Growth standards constrain z-scores outer tails (.e. past 3 z-scores), fewer data available extreme values. information constraining procedure can found reports referenced gigs::who_gs_value2zscore() documentation. childsds perform constraining procedure, extreme values computed incorrectly: look z-scores, can see growthstandards gigs correctly apply constraining procedure; childsds . looking anthro source code, also apply constraining procedure.
code: discrepancies <- data.frame(z = c(-3.03, -2.97, 2.97, 3.03),                             age_days = 0,                             sex = "M") |>   dplyr::mutate(     weight_kg = gigs::who_gs_wfa_zscore2value(z, age_days, sex),     # GIGS z-score     z_gigs = gigs::who_gs_wfa_value2zscore(weight_kg, age_days, sex),     # growthstandards z-score     z_growthstandards = growthstandards::who_wtkg2zscore(       age_days, weight_kg, "Male"     ),     # childsds z-score     z_childsds = childsds::sds(       value = weight_kg, age = age_days / 365.25,       sex = sex, male = "M", female = "F",       item = "weight", ref = childsds::who.ref     )   )

title: Introduction to gigs
text: Given outputs functions vectors, gigs functions integrate easily dplyr verbs.
code: df_newborn_weights <- data.frame(         weight_kg = c(0.91, 3.33, 2.75, 3.35, 3.47, 1.90),         gest_days = c(183, 280, 293, 259, 277, 231),         sex = c(rep("M", 3), rep("F", 3)) ) # Use the `acronym` parameter to specify the standard in use... df_newborn_weights$weight_p <- with(   df_newborn_weights,   ig_nbs_value2centile(y = weight_kg,                        gest_days = gest_days,                        sex = sex,                        acronym = "wfga")) |>   round(digits = 2)  # Or put the acronym in the function call for the standard-specific function df_newborn_weights$weight_z <- with(   df_newborn_weights,   ig_nbs_wfga_value2zscore(weight_kg = weight_kg,                            gest_days = gest_days,                            sex = sex)) |>   round(digits = 2) df_newborn_weights #>   weight_kg gest_days sex weight_p weight_z #> 1      0.91       183   M     0.65     0.37 #> 2      3.33       280   M     0.45    -0.14 #> 3      2.75       293   M     0.02    -2.14 #> 4      3.35       259   F     0.91     1.34 #> 5      3.47       277   F     0.74     0.65 #> 6      1.90       231   F     0.56     0.14

title: Introduction to gigs
text: addition generating continuous z-scores centiles, may wish classify attained growth. classification functions offered package allow user easily classify growth status:

title: Introduction to gigs
text: classify_sfga() function offers size GA classifications based cut-offs research literature. Typically, 10th 90th centiles used size GA cut-offs, publications also specify severely small--GA newborns third weight--GA centile. want use ‘severe’ cut-, just change severe parameter classify_sfga() TRUE:
code: df_newborn_weights$sga <- with(         df_newborn_weights,         classify_sfga(weight_kg = weight_kg, gest_days = gest_days, sex = sex)) df_newborn_weights$sga_severe <- with(         df_newborn_weights,         classify_sfga(weight_kg = weight_kg,                       gest_days = gest_days,                       sex = sex,                       severe = TRUE)) df_newborn_weights #>   weight_kg gest_days sex weight_p weight_z sga sga_severe #> 1      0.91       183   M     0.65     0.37 AGA        AGA #> 2      3.33       280   M     0.45    -0.14 AGA        AGA #> 3      2.75       293   M     0.02    -2.14 SGA    SGA(<3) #> 4      3.35       259   F     0.91     1.34 LGA        LGA #> 5      3.47       277   F     0.74     0.65 AGA        AGA #> 6      1.90       231   F     0.56     0.14 AGA        AGA

title: Introduction to gigs
text: classify_svn() function offers small, vulnerable newborn classifications, based framework set Lancet’s 2023 Small Vulnerable Newborn Series. Essentially, classify_svn() stratifies results classify_sfga() whether newborns term preterm:
code: df_newborn_weights$svn <- with(   df_newborn_weights,   classify_svn(weight_kg = weight_kg, gest_days = gest_days, sex = sex) ) df_newborn_weights #>   weight_kg gest_days sex weight_p weight_z sga sga_severe         svn #> 1      0.91       183   M     0.65     0.37 AGA        AGA Preterm AGA #> 2      3.33       280   M     0.45    -0.14 AGA        AGA    Term AGA #> 3      2.75       293   M     0.02    -2.14 SGA    SGA(<3)    Term SGA #> 4      3.35       259   F     0.91     1.34 LGA        LGA    Term LGA #> 5      3.47       277   F     0.74     0.65 AGA        AGA    Term AGA #> 6      1.90       231   F     0.56     0.14 AGA        AGA Preterm AGA

title: Introduction to gigs
text: classify_stunting() function offers stunting (length/height--age) classifications based cut-offs research literature. output factor levels corresponding different degrees stunting: can also specify classify_stunting() classify likely outlier/implausible values setting outliers parameter TRUE:
code: stunting_df <- data.frame(lenht_cm = c(52.2, 75.4, 63.1),                           age_days = c(357, 375, 250),                           gest_days = c(196, 287, 266),                           sex = c("M", "M", "F")) stunting_df$stunting <-   with(stunting_df,        classify_stunting(lenht_cm, age_days, gest_days, sex)) stunting_df #>   lenht_cm age_days gest_days sex        stunting #> 1     52.2      357       196   M stunting_severe #> 2     75.4      375       287   M    not_stunting #> 3     63.1      250       266   F        stunting stunting_df$stunting_out <-   with(stunting_df,        classify_stunting(lenht_cm, age_days, gest_days, sex, outliers = TRUE)) stunting_df #>   lenht_cm age_days gest_days sex        stunting stunting_out #> 1     52.2      357       196   M stunting_severe      outlier #> 2     75.4      375       287   M    not_stunting not_stunting #> 3     63.1      250       266   F        stunting     stunting

title: Introduction to gigs
text: classify_wasting() function offers wasting (weight--length) classifications based cut-offs research literature. output factor levels corresponding different degrees wasting: can also specify classify_wasting() classify likely outlier/implausible values setting outliers parameter TRUE:
code: wasting_df <- data.frame(weight_kg = c(5.75, 2.18, 3.00, 6.75),                          lenht_cm = c(64.6, 46.6, 50.0, 80.1),                          gest_days = c(268, 247, 250, 278),                          age_days = c(45, 33, 230, 278),                          sex =  c("F", "M", "F", "M")) wasting_df$wasting <-   with(wasting_df,        classify_wasting(weight_kg, lenht_cm, age_days, gest_days, sex)) wasting_df #>   weight_kg lenht_cm gest_days age_days sex        wasting #> 1      5.75     64.6       268       45   F    not_wasting #> 2      2.18     46.6       247       33   M        wasting #> 3      3.00     50.0       250      230   F    not_wasting #> 4      6.75     80.1       278      278   M wasting_severe wasting_df$wasting_out <-   with(wasting_df,        classify_wasting(weight_kg, lenht_cm, age_days, gest_days, sex, outliers = TRUE)) wasting_df #>   weight_kg lenht_cm gest_days age_days sex        wasting wasting_out #> 1      5.75     64.6       268       45   F    not_wasting not_wasting #> 2      2.18     46.6       247       33   M        wasting     wasting #> 3      3.00     50.0       250      230   F    not_wasting not_wasting #> 4      6.75     80.1       278      278   M wasting_severe     outlier

text: classify_wfa() function offers weight--age classifications based cut-offs research literature. output factor levels corresponding different degrees underweight overweight: can also specify classify_wasting() classify likely outlier/implausible values setting outliers parameter TRUE:
code: wfa_df <- data.frame(weight_kg = c(7.2, 4.5, 9.1, 24),                      age_days = c(401, 185, 101, 607),                      gest_days = 7 * c(27, 36, 40, 41),                      sex = c("F", "M", "F", "M")) wfa_df$wfa <- with(wfa_df, classify_wfa(weight_kg, age_days, gest_days, sex)) wfa_df #>   weight_kg age_days gest_days sex                wfa #> 1       7.2      401       189   F        underweight #> 2       4.5      185       252   M underweight_severe #> 3       9.1      101       280   F         overweight #> 4      24.0      607       287   M         overweight wfa_df$wfa_out <- with(         wfa_df,         classify_wfa(weight_kg, age_days, gest_days, sex, outliers = TRUE)) wfa_df #>   weight_kg age_days gest_days sex                wfa            wfa_out #> 1       7.2      401       189   F        underweight        underweight #> 2       4.5      185       252   M underweight_severe underweight_severe #> 3       9.1      101       280   F         overweight         overweight #> 4      24.0      607       287   M         overweight            outlier

title: INTERGROWTH-21st Body Composition Equations
text: Let’s first compare differences time fat-mass GA. column, ’ll subtract value previous row current row produce table differences (see check_differences() ). ’ll check differences row equal centiles, store all_equal column. Let’s check results fmfga_female: differences fat mass equal across percentiles gestational ages, according all_equal column. standard deviation (\(\sigma\)) changed gestational age (GA), all_equal age. hints centile curves, mean value (\(\mu\)) fat mass calculated first, summed product desired \(z\)-score/centile standard deviation (\(\sigma\)) constant across different GAs: \[\begin{align*} y = \mu + z\times\sigma \end{align*}\]
code: check_differences <- function(centile_tbl) {   centile_tbl |>     dplyr::mutate(dplyr::across(.cols = tidyselect::starts_with(match = "P"),                                 .fns = list(diff = \(x) x - dplyr::lag(x))),                   .keep = "unused") |>     dplyr::filter(dplyr::if_any(             tidyselect::starts_with(match = "P"), ~ !is.na(.))) |>     dplyr::rowwise() |>     dplyr::mutate(       all_equal = dplyr::n_distinct(P03_diff, P10_diff, P50_diff, P90_diff,                                     P97_diff, na.rm = TRUE),       all_equal = as.logical(all_equal)) |>     dplyr::ungroup() } check_differences(fmfga_female) ## # A tibble: 4 × 7 ##   gest_days P03_diff P10_diff P50_diff P90_diff P97_diff all_equal ##       <int>    <int>    <int>    <int>    <int>    <int> <lgl>     ## 1       273       33       33       33       33       33 TRUE      ## 2       280       34       34       34       34       34 TRUE      ## 3       287       31       31       31       31       31 TRUE      ## 4       294       23       23       23       23       23 TRUE

title: INTERGROWTH-21st Body Composition Equations
text: reconstruct standards, need determine equations \(\mu\) standard. also need calculate \(\sigma\), change GA.

title: INTERGROWTH-21st Body Composition Equations
text: following custom functions perform several tasks: run_LMs() fits models INTERGROWTH-21st normative body composition standard using lm(), returns fitted models list. std_deviation() determines \(\sigma\) given centile. extract_SDs() gets standard deviations centile GA. extract_eqn() uses functions extract ‘best possible’ equation standard use, prints console.
code: run_LMs <- function(df) {   model_linear <- lm(P50 ~ gest_days, data = df)   model_poly1 <- lm(P50 ~ poly(gest_days, degree = 1, raw = TRUE), data = df)   model_poly2 <- lm(P50 ~ poly(gest_days, degree = 2, raw = TRUE), data = df)   model_poly3 <- lm(P50 ~ poly(gest_days, degree = 3, raw = TRUE), data = df)   list(model_linear, model_poly1, model_poly2, model_poly3) }  #' Extract standard deviation from centiles #' @param P50 Value of y at mean #' @param PX Value of y at centile specified by `p` #' @param p Centile at which y = PX std_deviation <- function(P50, PX, p) (PX - P50) / qnorm(p = p)  extract_SDs <- function(df) {   stddev_03 <- std_deviation(df$P50, df$P03, p = 0.03)   stddev_10 <- std_deviation(df$P50, df$P10, p = 0.10)   stddev_90 <- std_deviation(df$P50, df$P90, p = 0.90)   stddev_97 <- std_deviation(df$P50, df$P97, p = 0.97)   stddevs <- c(stddev_03, stddev_10, stddev_90, stddev_97)   mean(stddevs, na.rm = TRUE) }  #' Extract equation and standard deviation; print to console #' @param df A centile table for `fmfga`, `bfpfga` or `ffmfga`. extract_eqn <- function(df, verbose = TRUE) {   li_models <- run_LMs(df)   r_sq_adj <- vapply(X = li_models,                      FUN = \(x) summary(x)$adj.r.squared,                      FUN.VALUE = numeric(length = 1L))   chosen_model <- li_models[[which(r_sq_adj == max(r_sq_adj))]]   if (!verbose) {     return(chosen_model)   }   model_coeffs <- coef(chosen_model)   coef_str <- lapply(     X = 2:length(model_coeffs),     FUN = \(x) {       start_str <- if (sign(model_coeffs[x]) == -1) "" else "+"       end_str <- if (x == 2) "* x" else paste0("* x^", x - 1)       paste(start_str, round(model_coeffs[x], 5), end_str)     }) |>     paste(collapse = " ")   sign_ <- if (sign(model_coeffs[2]) == -1) "" else "+"   cat(paste("y =", round(model_coeffs[[1]], 5), sign_, coef_str), sep = "\n")    SDs <- extract_SDs(df)    cat(paste("sigma =", round(mean(SDs, na.rm = TRUE), digits = 4)), sep = "\n")   invisible(chosen_model) }

title: INTERGROWTH-21st Body Composition Equations
text: First, bind coefficients model table. table can used look coefficients body composition standard. body_comp_centile2value() estimate y given gestational age days (x), sex acronym. body_comp_centile2value_old() function , uses parameters older linear models standard.
code: all_standards <- list(fmfga_male, fmfga_female, bfpfga_male, bfpfga_female,                       ffmfga_male, ffmfga_female) models <- lapply(all_standards, FUN = \(standard) {   model_coeffs <- standard |>     extract_eqn(verbose = FALSE) |>     coef() |>     t() |>     as.data.frame()   if (ncol(model_coeffs) == 3) model_coeffs$extra <- 0   names(model_coeffs) <- c("intercept", "x", "x^2", "x^3")   model_coeffs$SD <- extract_SDs(standard)   model_coeffs }) |>   do.call(what = "rbind") rownames(models) <- c("fmfga_M" , "fmfga_F" , "bfpfga_M", "bfpfga_F",                       "ffmfga_M", "ffmfga_F") models ##             intercept             x          x^2           x^3         SD ## fmfga_M   96787.80000 -1056.7738095  3.836734694 -0.0046161322 152.072842 ## fmfga_F   44432.51429  -490.7602041  1.803206997 -0.0021865889 156.844908 ## bfpfga_M   1521.84857   -16.6239796  0.060495627 -0.0000728863   3.656170 ## bfpfga_F    -66.09143     0.4810204 -0.000728863  0.0000000000   3.954716 ## ffmfga_M 347879.97143 -3780.5272109 13.730320700 -0.0165208941 276.509412 ## ffmfga_F 154457.42857 -1689.0085034  6.208454810 -0.0075315841 261.062458 ig_nbs_bc_centile2value <- function(p, x, sex, acronym) {   params <- t(models)[, paste0(acronym, "_", sex)]   SD <- params[[5]]   mu <- params[[1]] + params[[2]] * x + params[[3]] * x^2 + params[[4]] * x^3   mu + qnorm(p) * SD }  ig_nbs_bc_centile2value_old <- function(p, x, sex, acronym) {   z <- qnorm(p)   if (sex == "M") {     switch(acronym,            "fmfga"  = -1134.2 + 37.2  * x/7 + z * 152.1593,            "bfpfga" = -17.68  + 0.69  * x/7 + z * 3.6674,            "ffmfga" = -2487.6 + 139.9 * x/7 + z * 276.2276,            stop("Bad acronym", .call = F))   } else if (sex == "F") {     switch(acronym,            "fmfga"  = -840.2 + 30.7  * x/7 + z * 156.8411,            "bfpfga" = -9.02  + 0.51  * x/7 + z * 3.9405,            "ffmfga" = -1279  + 105.3 * x/7 + z * 260.621,            stop("Bad acronym", .call = F))   } }

code: #' Replicate centile tables as presented by Villar et al. repl_centile_tbls <- function(sex, acronym, bodycomp_fn) {   centiles <- c(0.03, 0.1, 0.5, 0.9, 0.97) |>     purrr::set_names(c("P03", "P10", "P50", "P90", "P97"))   tbl <- purrr::map(.x = centiles, .f = ~ {       p <- .x       column <- seq(266, 294, by = 7) |>         purrr::set_names(paste(1:5)) |>         purrr::map_dfc(.f  = ~ {           bodycomp_fn(p, .x, sex, acronym)         }) |>       t()     column[which(column <= 0)] <- NA_real_     as.data.frame(column)     })   tbl <- suppressMessages(suppressWarnings(dplyr::bind_cols(tbl)))   colnames(tbl) <- names(centiles)   dplyr::mutate(tbl, gest_days = (38:42 * 7), .before = P03) }  #' Make centile tables based on parameters from new polynomial models repl_centile_tbls_new <- function(sex, acronym) {   repl_centile_tbls(sex, acronym, ig_nbs_bc_centile2value) }  #' Make centile tables based on parameters from linear models repl_centile_tbls_old <- function(sex, acronym) {   repl_centile_tbls(sex, acronym, ig_nbs_bc_centile2value_old) }

text: Produced part Guidance International Growth Standards project, gigs provides single, simple interface working Child Growth standards outputs INTERGROWTH-21st project. find functions converting anthropometric measures (e.g. weight length) z-scores centiles, inverse. Also included functions classifying newborn infant growth according literature-based cut-offs. gigs use anyone interested fetal child growth, including child health researchers, policymakers, clinicians. package best suited growth data gestational age child known, use growth standards included gigs gestational age-dependent. recommend check available standards section see anthropometric measurements can converted z-scores/centiles gigs. recommend using gigs generate continuous categorical measures fetal/newborn/child growth, can used downstream analyses.

title: Assess Fetal, Newborn, and Child Growth with International Standards
text: package operates measured anthropometric values, can convert z-scores/centiles. Z-scores centiles represent location measurement within normal distribution values, : z-score number standard deviations mean given anthropometric measurement (e.g. height weight). centile represents proportion measurements distribution expect lower measurement ’ve taken, represented value 0 1.

title: Assess Fetal, Newborn, and Child Growth with International Standards
text: Conversion functions named according set standards use, component standard set, type conversion. example, convert values z-scores weight--GA standard INTERGROWTH-21st Newborn Size Standards : ig_nbs/_wfga/_value2zscore() Similarly, conversion length--age values centiles term preterm infants performed Child Growth standards INTERGROWTH-21st Postnatal Growth Preterm Infants standards, respectively: Term infants: who_gs/_lhfa/_value2zscore() Preterm infants: ig_png/_lfa/_value2centile() component standard included function call, passed acronym parameter general function call. example, two function calls behave way: vector acronym values can used want convert different standards input.
code: ig_nbs_value2zscore(y = 25.7, gest_days = 182, sex = "F", acronym = "hcfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 1.18  ig_nbs_hcfga_value2zscore(headcirc_cm = 25.7, gest_days = 182, sex = "F") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 1.18

title: Assess Fetal, Newborn, and Child Growth with International Standards
text: functions allow easy conversion measured values z-scores centiles standard used.
code: # Convert from z-scores for individual values... ig_nbs_value2zscore(y = 0.785, gest_days = 182, sex = "F", acronym = "wfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0  # .. or for multiple inputs ig_nbs_wfga_value2centile(weight_kg = 0.785,                           gest_days = seq(175, 196, by = 7),                           sex = "F") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.75 0.50 0.25 0.09  # You can do the same for centiles ig_png_wfa_value2centile(weight_kg = c(2.86, 3.12, 3.12, 3.43, 3.77, 4.10),                          pma_weeks = 40,                          sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.10 0.25 0.25 0.50 0.75 0.90

title: Assess Fetal, Newborn, and Child Growth with International Standards
text: functions convert z-scores expected anthropometric measurements. mostly useful creation reference curves (see ).
code: # Convert from z-scores for individual values... ig_nbs_zscore2value(z = 0, gest_days = 182, sex = "F", acronym = "wfga") |>   round(digits = 3) #> [1] 0.785  # .. or for multiple inputs ig_nbs_wfga_zscore2value(z = 0, gest_days = seq(182, 204, by = 7), sex = "F") |>   round(digits = 3) #> [1] 0.785 0.893 1.013 1.147  # You can do the same for centiles ig_png_wfa_centile2value(p = c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9),                             pma_weeks = 40,                             sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 2.87 3.12 3.43 3.77 4.11

title: Assess Fetal, Newborn, and Child Growth with International Standards
text: can use gigs generate reference curves standards getting curves expected weight multiple z-scores across multiple gestational ages. usually recommend ggplot2 visualisation, use reduce package’s dependencies.
code: z_score_range <- -2:2 gestage_range <- 168:230 ref <- mapply(z_score_range,                FUN = function(z) {                  gigs::ig_nbs_wfga_zscore2value(z = z,                                                 gest_days = gestage_range,                                                 sex = "F")                }) matplot(ref, x = gestage_range, col = 1:5, type = "l", lty = 2:6,         xlab = "Gestational age (days)",         ylab = "Weight (kg)") title(main = "Weight-for-GA in very preterm newborns") legend(x = min(gestage_range) + 1, y = ref[length(ref)], legend = 2:-2,        title = "Z-score", col = 5:1, lty = 2:6)

title: Assess Fetal, Newborn, and Child Growth with International Standards
text: functions allow quick identification -risk infants classification suboptimal growth. cut-offs used sourced research literature; can check function documentation see sources.
code: # Size for gestational age classify_sfga(   weight_kg = c(2.1, 3.2, 4.5),   gest_days = c(252, 259, 290),   sex = "M" ) #> [1] SGA AGA LGA #> Levels: SGA AGA LGA  # Small vulnerable newborns classify_svn(   weight_kg = c(2.1, 3.2, 4.5),   gest_days = c(252, 259, 290),   sex = "M" ) #> [1] Preterm SGA Term AGA    Term LGA    #> Levels: Preterm SGA Preterm AGA Preterm LGA Term SGA Term AGA Term LGA  # Stunting, i.e. low length increase relative to age classify_stunting(   lenht_cm = c(42.3, 75.4, 72.83),   age_days = c(252, 525, 245),   gest_days = c(238, 259, 266),   sex = "M" ) #> [1] stunting_severe stunting        not_stunting    #> Levels: stunting_severe stunting not_stunting  # Wasting, i.e. low weight increase relative to length/height classify_wasting(   weight_kg = c(5.75, 2.18, 5.30, 6.75),   lenht_cm = c(67.7, 46.6, 55.8, 80.1),   gest_days = c(268, 247, 250, 278),   age_days = c(45, 33, 230, 278),   sex = c("F", "M", "F", "M"), ) #> [1] wasting_severe wasting        not_wasting    wasting_severe #> Levels: wasting_severe wasting not_wasting overweight  # Weight-for-age, i.e. low weight increase relative to age classify_wfa(   weight_kg = c(2.1, 7.2, 6.1, 9.1, 9.4),   age_days = c(435, 501, 323, 201, 154),   gest_days = c(36, 27, 37, 40, 28),   sex = c("M", "M", "F", "F", "F") ) #> [1] underweight_severe underweight_severe normal_weight      overweight         #> [5] <NA>               #> Levels: underweight_severe underweight normal_weight overweight

title: Assess Fetal, Newborn, and Child Growth with International Standards
text: R packages can used analyse growth data international standards, limitations present gigs. also software packages external R implement standards. table describes packages, extent implemented functions let users convert anthropometric measurements z-scores/centiles set standards implemented gigs - Child Growth standards, INTERGROWTH-21st Newborn Size standards (including Preterm), INTERGROWTH-21st Postnatal Growth standards preterm infants. green tick (✅) indicates possible standards included package, red cross (❌) indicates standards completely missing, exclamation mark (❕) indicates standards implemented others. benchmarked implementations conversion values z-scores Child Growth standards. 100,000 inputs, package took: results can seen online benchmarking article. INTERGROWTH-21st standards also available standalone form, available website INTERGROWTH-21st website, respectively. INTERGROWTH-21st website also includes download links Excel-based calculators standards.

what: Classify size for gestational age using the INTERGROWTH-21st weight-for-gestational age standard — classify_sfga
title: Classify size for gestational age using the INTERGROWTH-21st weight-for-gestational age standard — classify_sfga
text: Size gestational age categories split centile: small--GA (SGA; 10th centile), appropriate--GA (AGA; 10th 90th centile) large--GA (LGA; >90th centile). function also supports classification severe SGA (<3rd centile) using severe parameter.

title: Classify size for gestational age using the INTERGROWTH-21st weight-for-gestational age standard — classify_sfga
code: classify_sfga(weight_kg, gest_days, sex, severe = FALSE)

title: Classify size for gestational age using the INTERGROWTH-21st weight-for-gestational age standard — classify_sfga
text: weight_kg Numeric vector length one weight value(s) kg. gest_days Numeric vector length one gestational age(s) birth days 168 300. default, gigs replace --bounds elements gest_days NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. sex Character vector length one sex(es), either "M" (male) "F" (female). argument case-sensitive. default, gigs replace elements sex "M" "F" NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. severe single logical value specifying whether categorise SGA values third centile "SGA(<3)". Default = FALSE.

title: Classify size for gestational age using the INTERGROWTH-21st weight-for-gestational age standard — classify_sfga
text: object class factor length longest input vector, containing size--GA classifications. severe = FALSE, levels c("SGA", "AGA", "LGA"). severe = TRUE, levels c("SGA(<3)", "SGA", "AGA", "LGA").

title: Classify size for gestational age using the INTERGROWTH-21st weight-for-gestational age standard — classify_sfga
text: Input vectors recycled vctrs::vec_recycle_common(), must adhere vctrs recycling rules.

title: Classify size for gestational age using the INTERGROWTH-21st weight-for-gestational age standard — classify_sfga
text: . Physical status: use interpretation anthropometry. Report Expert Committee. World Health Organisation Technical Report Series 1995, 854: 1–452 Royal College Obstetricians Gynaecologists. Investigation Management Small--Gestational-Age Fetus: Green-top Guideline . 31. Technical report, Royal College Obstetricians Gynaecologists, London, 2013.

title: Classify size for gestational age using the INTERGROWTH-21st weight-for-gestational age standard — classify_sfga
code: # By default, does not differentiate between p < 0.03 and p < 0.10 classify_sfga(   weight_kg = c(2.2, 3.3, 4.2),   gest_days = 267:269,   sex = c("M", "F", "M") ) #> [1] SGA AGA LGA #> Levels: SGA AGA LGA  # With severe = TRUE, highlights p < 0.03 classify_sfga(   weight_kg = c(2.2, 3.3, 4.2),   gest_days = 267:269,   sex = c("M", "F", "M"),   severe = TRUE ) #> [1] SGA(<3) AGA     LGA     #> Levels: SGA(<3) SGA AGA LGA

what: Classify stunting using WHO or INTERGROWTH-21st length/height-for-age standards — classify_stunting
title: Classify stunting using WHO or INTERGROWTH-21st length/height-for-age standards — classify_stunting
text: Classify stunting (low length/height--age) using INTERGROWTH-21st length/height--age standards depending gestational age birth child. Severe stunting <-3 SD relative mean length/height given age, whereas moderate stunting -2SD mean.

title: Classify stunting using WHO or INTERGROWTH-21st length/height-for-age standards — classify_stunting
code: classify_stunting(lenht_cm, age_days, gest_days, sex, outliers = FALSE)

title: Classify stunting using WHO or INTERGROWTH-21st length/height-for-age standards — classify_stunting
text: lenht_cm Numeric vector length one length/height measurement(s) cm. age_days Numeric vector length one age(s) days child. 0 1856 days. default, gigs replace --bounds elements age_days NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. gest_days Numeric vector gestational age(s) birth days. sex Character vector length one sex(es), either "M" (male) "F" (female). argument case-sensitive. default, gigs replace elements sex "M" "F" NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. outliers single TRUE FALSE value specifying whether implausible z-score value thresholds applied. Default = FALSE.

title: Classify stunting using WHO or INTERGROWTH-21st length/height-for-age standards — classify_stunting
text: object class factor length longest input vector, containing stunting classifications. levels c("stunting_severe", "stunting", "not_stunting") outliers = FALSE (default), else c("stunting_severe", "stunting", "not_stunting", "outlier").

title: Classify stunting using WHO or INTERGROWTH-21st length/height-for-age standards — classify_stunting
text: Input vectors recycled vctrs::vec_recycle_common(), must adhere vctrs recycling rules. function assumes measurements taken according guidelines, stipulate recumbent length measured 730 days. Implausible z-score bounds sourced referenced report, classification cut-offs DHS manual.

title: Classify stunting using WHO or INTERGROWTH-21st length/height-for-age standards — classify_stunting

'Percentage children stunted, wasted, underweight, mean z-scores stunting, wasting underweight' Guide DHS Statistics DHS-7 Rockville, Maryland, USA: ICF (2020). pp. 431-435. https://dhsprogram.com/data/Guide--DHS-Statistics/Nutritional_Status.htm

title: Classify stunting using WHO or INTERGROWTH-21st length/height-for-age standards — classify_stunting
code: # The first observation uses the INTERGROWTH-21st Postnatal Growth standards; # the next two use the WHO Child Growth Standards. classify_stunting(   lenht_cm = c(52.2, 75.4, 63.1),   age_days = c(357, 375, 250),   gest_days = c(196, 287, 266),   sex = c("M", "M", "F") ) #> [1] stunting_severe not_stunting    stunting        #> Levels: stunting_severe stunting not_stunting  # And with outlier flagging: classify_stunting(   lenht_cm = c(52.2, 75.4, 63.1),   age_days = c(357, 375, 250),   gest_days = c(196, 287, 266),   sex = c("M", "M", "F"),   outliers = TRUE ) #> [1] outlier      not_stunting stunting     #> Levels: stunting_severe stunting not_stunting outlier

what: Get and set gigs package options — gigs_options
title: Get and set gigs package options — gigs_options
text: default, gigs handle invalid input data, e.g. missing (NA) undefined (NaN, Inf -Inf) values, warning presence replacing invalid values NA. can change behaviour gigs_option_set() gigs silently, make gigs throw errors confronted bad data.

title: Get and set gigs package options — gigs_options
code: gigs_option_get(option, silent = FALSE)  gigs_option_set(option, new_value, silent = FALSE)

title: Get and set gigs package options — gigs_options
text: option single character variable, one : "handle_missing" - gigs handle missing (NA) data? "handle_undefined" - gigs handle undefined (NaN, Inf, -Inf) data? "handle_invalid_xvar" - gigs handle x variables bounds standard use? "handle_invalid_sex" - gigs handle elements sex one "M" "F"? "handle_invalid_acronym" - conversion functions, gigs handle acronym elements map onto implemented growth standard? "handle_invalid_centiles" - centile2value functions, gigs handle elements p 0 1? silent single logical value denoting whether function send message() console describing either: current value option gigs_option_get(). newly-set value option gigs_option_set(). new_value single character variable, one : "quiet" - gigs replace invalid vector elements NA quietly "warn" - gigs replace invalid vector elements NA loudly "error" - gigs throw informative errors invalid inputs encountered

title: Get and set gigs package options — gigs_options
text: gigs_option_get(), noisiliy returns current value option. gigs_option_set(), invisibly returns new value option.

title: Get and set gigs package options — gigs_options

title: Estimate gestational age using INTERGROWTH-21st predictive equations — ig_fet_estimate_ga
text: Vector inputs function recycled using vctrs::vec_recycle_common(). function attempt estimate gestational age (GA) three steps, highest lowest accuracy. First, using crown-rump length measurements obtained early pregnancy, head circumference femur length measurements, finally head circumference alone.

title: Convert values to z-scores/centiles in the INTERGROWTH-21st Fetal Growth standards — ig_fet_value2zscore
text: y Numeric vector length one anthropometric measurement(s) convert centiles/z-scores. Units depend acronym(s) use. x Numeric vector length one x values. Elements specific units certain values depending standard use (defined acronym). : 98 280 days "hcfga", "bpdfga", "acfga", "flfga", "ofdfga", "tcdfga". 154 280 days "efwfga". 112 294 days "sfhfga". 58 105 days "crlfga". 19 95 mm "gafcrl". 105 280 days "gwgfga". 168 280 days "pifga", "rifga", "sdrfga" (INTERGROWTH-21st Fetal Doppler standards). 105 252 days "poffga", "sffga", "avfga", "pvfga" (INTERGROWTH-21st Fetal Brain Development standards). default, gigs replace --bounds elements x NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. acronym Character vector length one denoting INTERGROWTH-21st Fetal Growth standard(s) use. value one : "hcfga" (head circumference--GA) "bpdfga" (biparietal diameter--GA) "acfga" (abdominal circumference--GA) "flfga" (femur length--GA) "ofdfga" (occipito-frontal diameter--GA) "efwfga" (estimated fetal weight--GA) "sfhfga" (symphisis-fundal height--GA) "crlfga" (crown-rump length--GA) "gafcrl" (GA--crown-rump length) "gwgfga" (gestational weight gain--GA) "pifga" (pulsatility index--GA) "rifga" (resistance index--GA) "sdrfga" (systolic/diastolic ratio--GA) "tcdfga" (transcerebellar diameter--GA) "poffga" (parieto-occipital fissure--GA) "sffga" (Sylvian fissure--GA) "avfga" (anterior horn lateral ventricle--GA) "pvfga" (atrium posterior horn lateral ventricle--GA) "cmfga" (cisterna magna--GA) argument case-sensitive. default, gigs replace elements acronym one values NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. elements acronym one values, gigs throw error. headcirc_mm Numeric vector length one head circumference measurements mm. gest_days Numeric vector length one usually used x variable, can also y variable "gafcrl" "gaftcd" standards. gest_days used x variable, bounds elements gest_days handled according gigs_options "handle_invalid_xvar". bpd_mm Numeric vector length one biparietal diameter measurement(s) mm. abdocirc_mm Numeric vector length one abdominal circumference measurement(s) mm. femurlen_mm Numeric vector length one femur length(s) mm. ofd_mm Numeric vector length one occipito-frontal diameter(s) mm. efw_g Numeric vector length one estimated fetal weight(s) g. sfh_cm Numeric vector length one symphisis-fundal height(s) mm. crl_mm Numeric vector length one crown-rump length(s) mm. gest_wt_gain_kg Numeric vector length one gestational weight gain(s)/loss(es) kg. puls_idx Numeric vector length one pulsatility index value(s). resist_idx Numeric vector length one resistance index value(s). sys_dia_ratio Numeric vector length one systolic/diastolic ratio value(s). tcd_mm Numeric vector length one transcerebellar diameter(s) mm. par_occ_fiss_mm Numeric vector length one parietal-occipital fissure measurement(s) mm. sylv_fiss_mm Numeric vector length one Sylvian fissure measurement(s) mm. ant_hlv_mm Numeric vector length one anterior horn lateral ventricle measurements(s) mm. atr_phlv_mm Numeric vector length one atrium posterior horn lateral ventricle measurement(s) mm. cist_mag_mm Numeric vector length one cisterna magna measurement(s) mm.

code: # Convert values to centiles ig_fet_value2centile(y = 335:345,                      x = 260:270,                      acronym = "hcfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #>  [1] 0.82 0.83 0.84 0.84 0.85 0.86 0.87 0.87 0.88 0.89 0.89  # Or values to z-scores ig_fet_value2zscore(y = 335:345,                     x = 260:270,                     acronym = "hcfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #>  [1] 0.92 0.95 0.98 1.01 1.04 1.07 1.11 1.14 1.18 1.21 1.25  # Specify which standard to use with the acronym parameter... ig_fet_value2zscore(y = 335:345,                     x = 260:270,                     acronym = "acfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #>  [1] 0.62 0.60 0.57 0.55 0.53 0.51 0.49 0.46 0.44 0.42 0.40  # ... or by using a standard-specific function ig_fet_acfga_value2zscore(abdocirc_mm = 335:345,                           gest_days = 260:270) |>   round(digits = 2) #>  [1] 0.62 0.60 0.57 0.55 0.53 0.51 0.49 0.46 0.44 0.42 0.40  # Inputs are recycled to the input of the longest length ig_fet_efwfga_value2zscore(efw_g = seq(3200, 3500, by = 50),                            gest_days = 280) |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] -0.34 -0.22 -0.09  0.03  0.15  0.28  0.40  # Bad inputs will not stop the function but will instead produce `NA`s in the # output - by default gigs will issue useful warnings ig_fet_hcfga_value2zscore(headcirc_mm = c(90, 100, 300, NaN),                           gest_days = c(91, 98, 224, 266)) |>   round(digits = 2) #> Warning: Variable 'headcirc_mm': 1 in 4 elements were undefined (`NaN`, `Inf`, or `-Inf`). #> Warning: Variable 'gest_days': 1 in 4 elements were out-of-bounds (see the 'ig_fet' conversion functions documentation). #> [1]   NA 0.38 0.59   NA

title: Convert z-scores/centiles to values in the INTERGROWTH-21st Newborn Size Standards — ig_nbs_centile2value
code: # Convert centiles to values ig_nbs_centile2value(p = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75),                      gest_days = 274:276,                      sex = c("F", "F", "F"),                      acronym = "wfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 2.90 3.17 3.46  # Or z-scores to values ig_nbs_zscore2value(z = qnorm(c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75)),                     gest_days = 280,                     sex = "M",                     acronym = "wfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 3.12 3.38 3.66  # Specify which standard to use with the acronym parameter... ig_nbs_zscore2value(z = qnorm(c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75)),                     gest_days = 280,                     sex = "M",                     acronym = "lfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 48.84 49.92 51.01  # ... or by using a standard-specific function ig_nbs_lfga_zscore2value(z = -2:2,                          gest_days = 278:282,                          sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 46.32 48.21 49.92 51.63 53.50  # Inputs are recycled to the input of the longest length ig_nbs_lfga_zscore2value(z = seq(0.1, 0.9, by = 0.2),                          gest_days = 280,                          sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 50.08 50.40 50.73 51.05 51.38  # Bad inputs will not stop the function but will instead produce `NA`s in the # output - by default gigs will issue useful warnings ig_nbs_hcfga_zscore2value(z = -0.5,                           gest_days = c(140, 182, 224, 266),                           sex = c("M", NA, "M", "M")) |>   round(digits = 2) #> Warning: Variable 'gest_days': 1 in 4 elements were out-of-bounds (see the 'ig_nbs' conversion functions documentation). #> Warning: Variable 'sex': 1 in 4 elements were missing (`NA`). #> [1]    NA    NA 28.66 32.88

text: y Numeric vector length one anthropometric measurement(s) convert centiles/z-scores. Units depend acronym(s) use. gest_days Numeric vector length one gestational ages days. Elements certain values depending Newborn Size standard use (defined acronym). : 168 300 days "wfga", "lfga", "hcfga", "wlrfga". 154 280 days "fmfga", "bfpfga", "ffmfga". default, gigs replace elements gest_days bounds growth standard use NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. sex Character vector length one sex(es), either "M" (male) "F" (female). argument case-sensitive. default, gigs replace elements sex "M" "F" NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. acronym Character vector length one denoting INTERGROWTH-21st Newborn Size standard use observation. element one : "wfga" (weight--GA) "lfga" (length--GA) "hcfga" (head circumference--GA) "wlrfga" (weight/length ratio--GA) "fmfga" (fat mass--GA) "bfpfga" (body fat %--GA) "ffmfga" (fat-free mass--GA) argument case-sensitive. default, gigs replace elements acronym one values NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. elements acronym one values, gigs throw error. weight_kg Numeric vector length one birth weight(s) kg. length_cm Numeric vector length one birth length(s) cm. headcirc_cm Numeric vector length one birth head circumference(s) cm. wei_len_ratio Numeric vector length one weight-length ratio(s) kg per m. fat_mass_g Numeric vector length one fat mass(es) g. body_fat_perc Numeric vector length one body fat percentage(s). fatfree_mass_g Numeric vector length one fat-free mass(es) g.

title: Convert values to z-scores/centiles in the INTERGROWTH-21st Newborn Size Standards — ig_nbs_value2centile
code: # Convert values to centiles ig_nbs_value2centile(y = c(2.90, 3.17, 3.46),                      gest_days = 274:276,                      sex = c("F", "F", "F"),                      acronym = "wfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.25 0.50 0.75  # Or values to z-scores ig_nbs_value2zscore(y = c(2.90, 3.17, 3.46),                     gest_days = 274:276,                     sex = c("F", "F", "F"),                     acronym = "wfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] -0.66  0.01  0.67  # Specify which standard to use with the acronym parameter... ig_nbs_value2zscore(y = 48.84,                     gest_days = 280,                     sex = "M",                     acronym = "lfga") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] -0.68  # ... or by using a standard-specific function ig_nbs_lfga_value2zscore(length_cm = 48.84,                          gest_days = 280,                          sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] -0.68  # Inputs are recycled to the input of the longest length ig_nbs_wlrfga_value2zscore(wei_len_ratio = c(7.37, 6.47, 6.12, 6.86),                            gest_days = 280,                            sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1]  0.85 -0.46 -0.97  0.11  # Bad inputs will not stop the function but will instead produce `NA`s in the # output - by default gigs will issue useful warnings ig_nbs_hcfga_value2centile(headcirc_cm = 34.0,                            gest_days = c(262, 264, 266, 301),                            sex = c(NA, "M", "M", "M")) |>   round(digits = 2) #> Warning: Variable 'gest_days': 1 in 4 elements were out-of-bounds (see the 'ig_nbs' conversion functions documentation). #> Warning: Variable 'sex': 1 in 4 elements were missing (`NA`). #> [1]   NA 0.71 0.67   NA

code: # Convert values to centiles ig_png_value2centile(y = c(5.79, 5.92, 7.25),                      x = 54:56,                      sex = c("M", "F", "M"),                      acronym = "wfa") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.25 0.50 0.75  # Or values to z-scores ig_png_value2zscore(y = c(5.79, 5.92, 7.25),                     x = 54:56,                     sex = c("M", "F", "M"),                     acronym = "wfa") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] -0.67  0.00  0.68  # Specify which standard to use with the acronym parameter... ig_png_value2zscore(y = c(60.2, 60.3, 64.1),                     x = 54:56,                     sex = c("M", "F", "M"),                     acronym = "lfa") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] -0.69  0.02  0.62  # ... or by using a standard-specific function ig_png_lfa_value2zscore(length_cm = c(60.2, 60.3, 64.1),                         pma_weeks = 54:56,                         sex = c("M", "F", "M")) |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] -0.69  0.02  0.62  # Inputs are recycled to the input of the longest length ig_png_lfa_value2zscore(length_cm = c(51.10, 51.48, 51.86, 52.24, 52.63),                         pma_weeks = 40,                         sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.1 0.3 0.5 0.7 0.9  # Bad inputs will not stop the function but will instead produce `NA`s in the # output - by default gigs will issue useful warnings ig_png_hcfa_value2centile(headcirc_cm = c(20.6, NA, 38.2, 42.8),                           pma_weeks = c(25, 27, 46, 64),                           sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> Warning: Variable 'headcirc_cm': 1 in 4 elements were missing (`NA`). #> Warning: Variable 'pma_weeks': 1 in 4 elements were out-of-bounds (see the 'ig_png' conversion functions documentation). #> [1]   NA   NA 0.65 0.43

title: Data extract from the Low birthweight Infant Feeding Exploration (LIFE) study — life6mo
text: data frame 2,511 rows 10 variables: id:  Unique ID infant dataset (1--300). gestage:  Best obstetric estimate gestational age days (201--311). sex:  Sex infant factor ("M" = Male; "F" = Female). visitweek:  Chronological age weeks (±1) study visit occurred (0--26). pma:  Post-menstrual age days (202--545). age_days:  Chronological age days visit; equal pma - gestage (0--245). weight_g:  Mean weight g (1271.67--9050.00). len_cm:  Mean length cm (35.03--72.93). headcirc_cm:  Mean head circumference cm (23.20--45.17). muac_cm:  Mean mid-upper arm circumference cm (6.13--17.03).

title: Data extract from the Low birthweight Infant Feeding Exploration (LIFE) study — life6mo

text: y Numeric vector length one anthropometric measurement(s) convert centiles/z-scores. Units depend acronym(s) use. x, age_days, length_cm, height_cm Numeric vector length one x values. Elements x standard-specific equivalents (age_days, length_cm, height_cm) specific units certain values depending standard use (defined acronym). : 0 1856 days "wfa", "bfa", "lhfa", "hcfa". 45 110 days "wfl". 65 120 days "wfh". 91 1856 days "acfa", "ssfa", "tsfa". default, gigs replace --bounds elements x NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. sex Character vector length one sex(es), either "M" (male) "F" (female). argument case-sensitive. default, gigs replace elements sex "M" "F" NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. acronym Character vector length one denoting Child Growth standard(s) use. element one : "wfa" (weight--age) "bfa" (BMI--age) "lhfa" (length/height--age) "wfl" (weight--length) "wfh" (weight--height) "hcfa" (head circumference--age) "acfa" (arm circumference--age) "ssfa" (subscapular skinfold--age) "tsfa" (triceps skinfold--age) argument case-sensitive. default, gigs replace elements acronym one values NA warn . behaviour can customised using functions gigs_options. elements acronym one values, gigs throw error. weight_kg Numeric vector length one weight measurement(s) kg. bmi Numeric vector length one body mass index measurement(s) kg/m2. lenht_cm Numeric vector length one length/height measurement(s) cm. headcirc_cm Numeric vector length one head circumference measurement(s) cm. armcirc_cm Numeric vector length one arm circumference measurement(s) cm. subscap_sf_mm Numeric vector length one subscapular skinfold measurement(s) mm. triceps_sf_mm Numeric vector length one triceps skinfold measurement(s) mm.

title: gigs 0.4.1
text: Changes documentation facilitate autotest::autotest_package() pass. Minor changes vignettes new patched version.

title: gigs 0.4.0
text: Changed name classify_sga() classify_sfga() Added INTERGROWTH-21st Fetal standards, including Fetal Growth standards, Fetal Doppler standards, Brain Development, ! INTERGROWTH-21st Postnatal Growth (ig_png) conversion functions now accept post-menstrual age weeks (pma_weeks) either whole weeks decimals, e.g. 37 37.142857, 37.142857 equal 37 weeks + 1 day, 37 + 1/7 weeks. See documentation allowed data types/lengths function argument. gigs package options via .gigs_options, lets customise warning error behaviour see fit. Added statistical review roclets tags. Better documentation, compliance SRR tags. Internal, non-breaking changes test suite documentation.
